articles.content:
Snow Drought Hits the Western United States, Worrying Experts About the Regionâ€™s Water Supply
Snow melt from the mountains provides up to 75 percent of the Westâ€™s yearly water
While winter weather blanketed much of the United States in snow last week, mountains in the western part of the country are sparser than usual. The amount of compressed snow, or snowpack, in some spots has hit historical lows, culminating in a snow drought.
Coloradoâ€™s snowpack is â€œthe lowest on record for this point in the season,â€ Peter Goble, the assistant state climatologist of Colorado, tells Evan Bush at NBC News. Utah is in a similar situation, per the outlet, as well as certain places in California, says Daniel Swain, a climate scientist at the University of California Agriculture and Natural Resources, in an online presentation.
â€œAt least one ground-based monitoring station in every major western watershed recorded the lowest [amount of water stored in the snowpack] in at least 20 years on January 26,â€ according to a statement from the NASA Earth Observatory.
Thatâ€™s not just bad news for winter sports enthusiasts. Snowpack is a natural reservoir of fresh water, which slowly melts and provides up to 75 percent of the Westâ€™s annual water supply. The diminished snowmelt will likely add to the megadrought currently burdening the Colorado River, and it could exacerbate regional wildfires come summer.
The snow drought seems to partially be a consequence of unusually toasty temperatures. â€œWashington, Oregon, California and many Western states had their warmest December ever on record,â€ Philip Mote, a climate scientist at Oregon State University, tells NBC News. â€œAnd so, the torrential rains that we had with the atmospheric river and the flooding and damage from too much waterâ€”none of that stayed in the mountains.â€
Instead, the Pacific Northwestâ€™s rainstorm that took place from December 1 to December 15 melted much of the snow, and â€œparadoxically left the regionâ€™s water supplies worse off in its wake,â€ writes Alejandro N. Flores, a hydrologist at Boise State University, for the Conversation.
Quick fact: Whatâ€™s an atmospheric river?
Much like a traditional river, these are long, thin areas in the atmosphere that move water vapor. They transport the vapor out of the tropics and dump it elsewhere as rain or snow.
And more recently, much of the West has been experiencing an unusually long dry spell, meaning the snowpack isnâ€™t getting replenished.
Scientists canâ€™t pinpoint the exact reasons for the regionâ€™s recent weather conditions, since itâ€™s difficult to attribute the snow drought to climate change alone, reports Jim Robbins at the New York Times. Still, computer simulations that forecast weather suggest that the events arenâ€™t merely a one-off.
â€œThe predictions are we will get less snow because the precipitation base will be rain rather than snow, and the line at which snow accumulates will keep creeping up,â€ says McKenzie Skiles, a snow hydrologist at the University of Utah, to the outlet.
The snow drought comes at an already bleak time for the Colorado River basin, which supplies water to 40 million people and has been experiencing a historic drought since 2000. Western states have been negotiating management of the riverâ€™s dwindling resources for years, and the snow drought makes the situation even more pressing. More than half of the Westâ€™s runoff, water that flows into bodies of water, comes from snowmelt, according to a 2017 study.
Policymakers from seven states met last Friday to reach a new water-sharing agreement, but for now, they remain at an impasse. â€œIn the short run, having a low snowpack year may raise the urgency of coming to some of those agreements,â€ Goble tells NBC News.
The conditions have also affected the regionâ€™s ski industry. For instance, the company Vail Resorts said that only 11 percent of its terrain in the Rocky Mountains was open in December, and that snowfall then and during the previous month was 60 percent below average, reports the New York Times.
February and March might bring more snow, although that may not make up for the current deficit. â€œIn places such as the Pacific Northwest and the Colorado River Basin that are already dry, snow drought may turn into or exacerbate traditional drought,â€ per the statement.
Additionally, more arid conditions could exacerbate wildfire risk by creating an abundance of dried plant matter, which is the primary fuel for fires. Climate change-enhanced drying has roughly doubled the area of forest fires in the West from 1984 to 2015, according to a 2016 study.
Experts are now working on ways to better predict snow drought and its consequencesâ€”work that will become more important as the events become more common, Flores writes for the Conversation.

A New App Can Match Footprints to the Dinosaurs That Made Them
Using artificial intelligence, DinoTracker can accurately classify dinosaur tracks around 90 percent of the time
New inventions can come from unexpected places. After reading a book on the history of dinosaurs to his son, physicist Gregor Hartmann realized that the artificial intelligence methods he worked on in photon science might have an application in paleontology. He reached out to the bookâ€™s author, paleontologist Steve Brusatte, with the idea, and DinoTracker was born. The new model uses A.I. to classify fossilized tracks to different dinosaur species.
Hartmannâ€™s team published the modelâ€™s findings in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences last week, and the DinoTracker app is now available on GitHub.
Until now, most paleontologists have identified dinosaur tracks in fossils manually or based on previous classifications, which can sometimes lead to biases or misclassifications, Hartmann tells the Guardianâ€™s Nicola Davis.
â€œYou never find a footprint and alongside [it] the dinosaur that had made this footprint,â€ Hartmann says. â€œSo, no offense to palaeontologists and such, but most likely some of these labels are wrong.â€
Unlike previous models, DinoTracker was trained on almost 2,000 unlabeled dinosaur footprints, which it sorted into classifications based on eight key characteristics. These included spread of toes, amount of ground contact and heel position. After over a year of training the neural network, the model aligned with human classifications around 90 percent of the time.
â€œI wish there was an app like this when I first started studying dinosaur tracks,â€ Brusatte, who co-authored the report in PNAS, says to Rachael Funnell at IFL Science. â€œIt really is challenging to understand the variation among tracks that were made by different dinosaurs and preserved in different environments, and this app now makes everything more objective.â€
Because the modelâ€™s only input is the track itself, human experts still oversee and confirm the classification based on additional context of age and location.
â€œThis app certainly isnâ€™t the end of the story when it comes to puzzling over the mysteries of dinosaur footprints,â€ Paige dePolo, the reportâ€™s co-author, writes in the Conversation. â€œItâ€™s a useful research resource for figuring out what tracks any footprint is most similar to in terms of shape, and what features are driving that similarity.â€
DinoTracker also supported paleontologistsâ€™ previous observations that some three-toed dinosaur tracks are remarkably similar to bird tracks. This confirmation from an unbiased, computational source is significant, Brusatte tells IFLScience
â€œOur dinosaur footprint A.I. model shows that some of these mysterious, controversial three-toed Triassic tracks really do resemble those of birds,â€ he says. â€œThe humans studying them were correct. It wasn't just wishful thinking, or that they were seeing a bird shape in the tracks in the same way somebody imagines the face of Jesus on a slice of toast.â€
This raises the hypothesis that birds or bird ancestors originated nearly 60 million years before scientists previously thought. But tracks are not a perfect representation of the creature that made them, dePolo writes in the Conversation.
Fun fact: Record-setting site
- Bolivia's Torotoro National Park is home to 16,600 exposed three-toed dinosaur footprintsâ€”the most ever found in one location.
â€œDinosaur footprints are not perfect snapshots of the feet that made them," she writes. "They reflect the shape of the foot, how the dinosaur was moving, and how soft or hard the ground was at the time.â€
Jens Lallensack, a geoscientist at Humboldt University of Berlin, who has also used A.I. to help identify dinosaur tracks but was not involved in the study, tells the Guardian that the birdlike tracks do not directly reflect the shape of the foot and â€œare not evidence for an early appearance of birds.â€
The scholars have made the model publicly available as an app on GitHub for both expert and amateur dinosaur lovers.
â€œI think A.I. has a bright future in paleontology,â€ Brusatte tells IFLScience. â€œIt's not that A.I. will become some all-knowing god that can identify every single fragment of dinosaur bone or tell us exactly where to find every fossil in the rocks. But what excites me most is that A.I. can become a new type of paleontologist, one that compiles and observes and filters through and classifies data and does so in a way that is free from the usual human biases.â€

Megalodons Went Extinct Millions of Years Ago. The Prehistoric Predator Could Become Marylandâ€™s Official State Shark
Teeth belonging to the fearsome creatures have been discovered throughout the state. Now, theyâ€™re up for consideration by the state legislature
For nearly 20 million years, megalodons prowled the worldâ€™s oceans. The massive creatures, which could grow up to 80 feet long and weighed about 94 tons, used their large teeth and strong jaws to subdue whatever prey they encounteredâ€”from whales and large fish to other sharks.
The fearsome predators went extinct roughly 3.6 million years ago. But theyâ€™re still making waves today: Maryland is now considering whether to make the megalodon its official state shark, reports WMAR-2 Newsâ€™ Megan Knight.
The effort is spearheaded by Stephen Godfrey, curator of paleontology at the Calvert Marine Museum in southern Maryland, and his colleague John Nance, who serves as the museumâ€™s paleontology collections manager.
They say the discovery of megalodon teeth throughout the state makes the prehistoric giant worthy of the designation. The creaturesâ€™ fossilized remains have turned up in numerous Maryland counties, and the Calvert Marine Museum has several on display.
Did you know? Calvert Cliffs
- One of the most popular sites for finding megalodon teeth is the Calvert Cliffs area of southern Maryland.
- Prehistoric fossils often emerge as the waves and the wind erode the cliffs.
Paleontologists have also discovered evidence of a possible megalodon attack: a pair of 15-million-year-old fractured whale backbones. The teeth of several other prehistoric shark species have also been found in Maryland, which scientists think was once a feeding and calving ground for numerous extinct species.
â€œTurns out no state has a state shark, so weâ€™re hoping Maryland is the first,â€ Godfrey tells WMAR-2 News. â€œTo me, this is such an iconic animal. I think itâ€™s time for megalodon to take center stage as the first shark designated as a state shark.â€
Godfrey and Nance helped write two billsâ€”one for each chamber of the state legislatureâ€”which were introduced for first reading on January 14, per WBOCâ€™s Sean Curtis. If the legislation passes, megalodon would become Marylandâ€™s state shark on October 1, 2026. The gargantuan beasts would then join other state symbols, such as the Baltimore oriole, the white oak and the black-eyed susan.
â€œThe megalodon, although extinct, lived in this area for millions of years and is a reminder of the important role modern and prehistoric sharks have played in shaping past and present ecosystems,â€ according to House Bill 97.
Though Maryland might become the first to adopt a shark, states have honored prehistoric creatures in other ways. Minnesota, for instance, recently named the giant beaver its state fossil. About the size of a small bear, the creatures roamed the area that is now the Twin Cities more than 10,000 years ago. Other official state symbols include the mammoth (Nebraska), Stegosaurus (Colorado), the mastodon (Michigan) and the ichthyosaur (Nevada).

articles.content:
This Rare Roman Figurine of a Cat With Its Paws Atop a Severed Head Is One of Britainâ€™s Newest Treasures
The artifact was discovered by a metal detectorist in 2024
In 2024, a metal detectorist in England stumbled upon a rare artifact: a metal figurine depicting a panther with its paws atop a bearded manâ€™s severed head.
The item, which dates to between 43 and 200 C.E., was recently featured at an event at the British Museum, alongside two other artifacts that had also been deemed â€œtreasureâ€ by the British government. That designation now makes it possible for a museumâ€”in this case, Englandâ€™s Epping Forest District Museumâ€”to acquire the cat ornament and put it on display.
The roughly four-inch-long piece is mostly three-dimensional, but the back side is hollow and filled with lead, according to its official government description. Experts say the item probably once adorned a Roman-era carriage that belonged to a high-status individualâ€”a successful farmer or merchant, for example.
The carriage fitting, which is made of a copper alloy, has a blue-green patina from the centuries it spent in the dirt. But while it was in use, it was likely a bright, yellow-orange hue. â€œYou could see it gleaming and youâ€™d know whose carriage it was coming towards you,â€ John Pearce, an archaeologist with Kingâ€™s College London, tells BBC Newsâ€™ Katy Prickett.
Fun fact: Fascinating finds
Other notable artifacts unearthed in 2024 include 179 silver pennies with ties to Harold II and an early medieval bird head figure made of silver, gold, garnet and ivory, per the Guardianâ€™s Nadia Khomami.The figure, which was probably one part of a pair, was likely meant to symbolize the strength and power of the Roman Empire. The panther probably represented Bacchus, the Roman name for the Greek god Dionysus, the â€œparty god.â€ The severed head, meanwhile, likely depicted one of the empireâ€™s many enemies.
Researchers were surprised when the artifact turned up near Harlow, a village roughly 30 miles north of London, because Roman carriage fittings were often melted down. It also features a unique blend of Roman-British design, combining the geometric patterns that were prevalent in Britain during the Iron Age with traditional Roman victory imagery.
This uncommon aesthetic was used â€œto produce something that represents Romeâ€™s conquest over Britain,â€ according to a January 20 Facebook post from the Essex Portable Antiquities Scheme, the group tasked with recording local archaeological finds on behalf of the British government.
â€œThis is unparalleled in vehicle fittings across the Empire, making this example unique,â€ according to the post.
The design sets this figurine apart, but similar items have surfaced before. A metal detectorist near Great Dunham, Norfolk, for example, once found a carriage ornament depicting a tigress. But it was made of silver and copper, and it was much larger; it also appears to have had a different, slot-style attachment mechanism. Another specimen, which depicts a female panther with its paw on a medallion, is housed at a museum in the eastern part of the country.
The cat figurine was one of 79,616 artifacts discovered by members of the publicâ€”mostly metal detectoristsâ€”and reported to British authorities in 2024. Thatâ€™s a new record, and an increase from the 74,506 items reported in 2023 and the 53,490 reported in 2022.
In 2023, in a bid to put more national treasures on display, the government expanded the law that requires finders to report their discoveries. The cat figurine, unearthed after the amendment took effect, â€œtypifies why this change was so important for protecting our heritage so we can understand our origins, but more importantly, ourselves better,â€ Lori Rogerson, the local liaison officer for the county where the artifact was discovered, tells BBC News.
The discovery of this and other artifacts is a â€œtestament to the dedication of finders across the country,â€ says Ian Richardson, who works at the British Museum and oversees the governmentâ€™s portable antiquities and treasure program, in a statement. â€œTheir responsible reporting allows us to build a richer and more detailed picture of life in the past, while ensuring that important objects are preserved for public benefit.â€
